text: The Bahamas, officially the Commonwealth of The Bahamas, is expected to compete at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo. Originally scheduled to take place from 24 July to 9 August 2020, the Games have been postponed to 23 July to 8 August 2021, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. It will be the nation's eighteenth consecutive appearance at the Summer Olympics. ==Athletics== Bahamian athletes achieved the entry standards, either by qualifying time or by world ranking, in the following track and field events (up to a maximum of 3 athletes in each event): ;Track & road events {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Heat !colspan="2"|Quarterfinal !colspan="2"|Semifinal !colspan="2"|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Result !Rank !Result !Rank !Result !Rank !Result !Rank |-align=center |align=left|Samson Colebrooke |align=left|Men's 100 m |colspan=2 | | | | | | |-align=center |align=left|Steven Gardiner |align=left|Men's 400 m | | |colspan=2 | | | | |-align=center |align=left rowspan=2|Tynia Gaither |align=left|Women's 100 m |colspan=2 | | | | | | |-align=center |align=left|Women's 200 m | | |colspan=2 | | | | |-align=center |align=left rowspan=2|Shaunae Miller-Uibo |align=left|Women's 200 m | | |colspan=2 | | | | |-align=center |align=left|Women's 400 m | | |colspan=2 | | | | |-align=center |align=left|Pedrya Seymour |align=left|Women's 100 m hurdles | | |colspan=2 | | | | |} ;Field events {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Qualification !colspan="2"|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Distance !Position !Distance !Position |-align=center |align=left|Jamal Wilson |align=left|Men's high jump | | | | |} ==See also== *Bahamas at the 2019 Pan American Games ==References== Category:Nations at the 2020 Summer Olympics 2020 Category:2020 in Bahamian sport
